item.title: How to Copy Webpage Style Sheets (CSS): Element Inspection
item.description:
The themes for static blogs are mostly based on foreign templates, with modifications and adjustments, without much consideration for the layout of Chinese content

Main body

About half a month ago, I made some adjustments to the blog’s stylesheet. Having worked in backend service development for many years, I’m quite the newbie when it comes to frontend. After fiddling with it all day, the design wasn’t very reasonable. Suddenly, I had an idea – remembering the technical blogs I often read: InfoQ and Open Source China, their layouts are really good. Could I borrow some of their ideas? I looked at the source code for a while, trying to locate the relevant elements, but ended up completely confused.

Frontend developers seeing this might be laughing… not understanding how to locate specified elements. It’s okay if you don’t understand, there’s plenty of time on the weekend, so let me pause and think – it seems I used something similar when writing Python crawlers before.

Elemental Review

It’s true, it’s the browser’s built-in element inspection tool – copying style sheets and locating specific elements are done in a flash; selector locates elements, hugo creates user define css

  • Copy element
  • Copy outerHTML
  • Copy selector
  • Copy JS path
  • Copy Style
  • Copy XPath
  • Copy the complete XPath
